parts: Name this animal which was captured during the seventh labor of Heracles and relocated to Marathon.
Poseidon caused Pasiphaë (pah-SIF-ah-ee) to conceive a lust for the Cretan bull, leading to the birth of this creature who lived in the Labyrinth.

This son of Minos and Pasiphaë was killed in Athens, either out of jealousy over winning an athletic contest or during an attempt to hunt the Cretan Bull. Minos demanded Athenians sacrifice their children to the Minotaur after starting a war with Athens over this figure’s death.

answers: subcutaneous injections [or SC or SQ or sub-cu or sub-Q or subcut injections; accept subcutaneous layer]

iontophoresis [accept quantitative pilocarpine iontophoresis test; prompt on QPIT; prompt on electrophoresis or electroosmosis or electromotive drug delivery with "what technique is used to induce electrophoresis?"]
parts: Give the term for this method of drug administration that may make use of an EpiPen, which delivers drugs to a layer of the skin beyond the dermis and epidermis.

Subcutaneous injections penetrate deeper into the skin than transdermal treatments like pharmaceutical patches do. Those patches can be used to deliver this alkaloid molecule to treat tobacco addiction.

Drugs can also be delivered transdermally using this method in which a voltage is applied to skin. It can treat hyperhidrosis (hyper-hi-DROH-sis), in which excess sweating occurs, and pilocarpine (pil-luh-KAHR-peen) is administered in this way in sweat tests for cystic fibrosis.

answers: Ian McEwan (the second novel is Atonement)
parts: Name this British author who depicted William Bradshaw's encounters with a French Communist spy in Mr. Norris Changes Trains.

Mr. Norris Changes Trains is the second half of a series by Isherwood known as the "stories" of this city. A 1929 novel by Alfred Döblin depicts ex-con Franz Biberkopf's life on this German city's Alexanderplatz.
Leonard Marnham does intelligence work in West Berlin in this author's novel The Innocent. This author of Amsterdam wrote a novel in which Briony Tallis writes a happy ending for Robby and Cecilia.
Name this group of screenwriters, including Dalton Trumbo and Ring Lardner Jr., who were blacklisted after HUAC accused them of engaging in communist activity.

The Hollywood Ten were blacklisted during the second of these events, during which Cold War tensions heightened the fear of Soviet spying and sabotage against the United States. The first of these events took place following the end of World War I.

In 1947, this man testified that he received literature supporting a "Committee for a Far-Eastern Democratic Policy" from the Screen Actors Guild. Under the codename "T-10," this man provided names of potential communist sympathizers to the FBI.
Name this two-word phrase that titles a paper by Candace West and Don Zimmerman which reevaluates Harold Garfinkel's study of the transgender woman Agnes Torres.
This UC Berkeley gender theorist explained the idea of doing gender in terms of "gender performativity" in her magnum opus Gender Trouble.

West and Zimmerman took inspiration from this sociologist's article "Gender Display." This developer of "dramaturgical" analysis discussed depictions of the "feminine touch" in billboards and commercials in his book Gender Advertisements.

answers: The Old Man and the Sea
parts: Name this author who compared Ted Williams to Hamlet when discussing his final game in the New Yorker essay "Hub Fans Bid Kid Adieu."
Ted Williams was a contemporary of Joe DiMaggio, a baseball player idolized by the protagonist of this Ernest Hemingway novel about the aging fisherman Santiago.

Baseball player Ethan Feld and his team save Cam Island from destruction in this author's novel Summerland. This author wrote about Meyer Landsman and other residents of a Jewish refugee settlement in Alaska in The Yiddish Policemen's Union.

answers: griots (GREE-ohs) [accept djeli or djali; accept kevel or guewel or gawlo or iggawin or diari or gesere]
parts: Name these West African storytellers. In the court of the Malian Empire, these bards would frequently perform The Epic of Sundiata.

Kanuri griots sing of how this empire's ruler Idris Alooma sought ruling advice from eight-foot-tall Sao giants. The Girgam chronicles this empire, which fueled the Tunisian slave market with frequent wars against the Bulala.

The Haddad people of Kanem-Bornu frequently became griots, but are better known for blacksmithing practices similar to those of this other ethnic group. This ethnolinguistic group spread across Central Africa during a namesake "migration" around 200 AD.
Name this composer of the motet Spem in Alium whose setting of Psalm 2 became the basis of a Ralph (rafe) Vaughan Williams "fantasia."

Tallis's music marked the transition away from this Renaissance technique, in which a single syllable is held across a note spanning multiple pitches. Anthony Heilbut noted that this technique has re-entered popular music due to heavy use in gospel songs and a preference for it on American Idol.

This student of Tallis, who shared a 21-year patent on publishing polyphonic music in England, wrote Ye Sacred Muses to commemorate Tallis's death. This author composed the collection My Ladye Nevells Booke (Lady Nevell's book) for virginal.

answers: Francis Poulenc (poo-LAWNK) [or Francis Jean Marcel Poulenc]
parts: Name this opera-oratorio from Igor Stravinsky's neoclassical period with a libretto in Latin. Its title character confesses to a murder in the aria "Ego senem kekidi."
In his sixth Norton Lecture, Leonard Bernstein suggested that the four opening chords of the male chorus in Oedipus Rex were based on a motif from this other composer's opera Aida.

The libretto for Oedipus Rex is by Jean Cocteau, whose play La voix humaine (lah vwah oo-MEN) was the basis for this composer's opera of the same name. This member of Les Six (lay see) wrote the opera Dialogues of the Carmelites.

answers: isotropy [or word forms such as isotropic; prompt on rotational or spherical symmetry with "what property implies spherical symmetry at all points?"]
Galileo Galilei [accept either name; accept Galilean relativity or Galilean transformations]
parts: Name this quantity. Kinetic energy is equal to one half times mass times the square of this quantity.

The fact that kinetic energy is proportional to the square of velocity can be derived from this property of space, since it implies that only the magnitude of the velocity is relevant in the calculation of the Lagrangian.

Both the isotropy of space and a principle of relativity named for this scientist must be invoked to derive the exact form of kinetic energy. Transformations named for this scientist are the non-relativistic analogue of Lorentz transformations.

answers: an automaton [accept a robot or a doll; accept The Automata]
night [accept nacht; accept Night Pieces or Hymns to the Night; accept Nachtstücke or Hymnen an die Nacht]
parts: Name this type of character whose playing of the harpsichord and stiff dancing enraptures Nathanael, causing him to abandon his fiancée Clara.

Nathanael's creator, E.T.A. Hoffmann, also wrote a novella about this character, who takes Marie to a kingdom of dolls. This character defeats the Mouse King and titles the Tchaikovsky ballet adapted from that novella.

Hoffmann wrote about Nathanael's love for Olimpia in a story collection titled for this time. The speaker laments, "The end, just like a harp's sigh, comes light" in a set of poems titled for this time which includes "Longing for Death."

answers: black [or black theology; or black liberation theology; or Black Power]
parts: Give this adjective. Cone's brand of liberation theology was influenced by a movement named for this kind of "Power" that was led by people such as Malcolm X.

This Union student found the seminary far less interesting than Adam Clayton Powell Sr.'s Abyssinian (a-bih-sin-ian) Baptist Church in nearby Harlem. Powell inspired the concept of "cheap grace" found in this German's book The Cost of Discipleship.

This Union professor turned his interviews with Christa Buschendorf (buh-shen-doorf) into the book Black Prophetic Fire. This pragmatist critiqued the "Manichaean (man-ih-kee-ahn) theology" of Malcolm X in Race Matters.

answers: tryptophan [or trp or W; accept tryptophan synthase or the trp operon]
folate [or folic acid; or vitamin B9; accept tetrahydrofolate or tetrahydrofolic acid or THF; prompt on vitamin B]
parts: Name this molecule. Attenuation was discovered in E. Coli for disrupting its synthesis.

Thymidylate synthase forms an "electrostatic highway" that allows for substrate channelling with DHFR, an enzyme that produces the tetrahydro-form of this vitamin. With vitamin B12, it is involved in one carbon transfer reactions, like the conversion from uracil to thymine.
In a cascade reaction that utilizes substrate channeling, this molecule's namesake dehydrogenase complex converts it into acetyl-CoA. This three-carbon molecule is the final product of glycolysis.
Name this artist, whose work Cathedra was also attacked by van Bladeren. Like many of this Color Field painter's works, Cathedra has a "zip," or a vertical line, down the middle.

This Soviet artist declared the "death of painting" while exhibiting monochrome red, yellow, and blue canvases at the 5x5=25 exhibition. This constructivist artist responded to Malevich's (mull-YEV-itch'z) White on White with the Black on Black series.

An untitled composition consisting of red, yellow, and blue rectangles was one of many similar works this Latvian-American Color Field artist produced. He was also commissioned for the Seagram Murals.

answers: Troyes [accept Treaty of Troyes; or hot fair of Troyes; or cold fair of Troyes]
parts: Name this French region which is home to a cathedral that has hosted every French coronation since Hugh Capet in 987. Dom Pérignon (pay-REE-nyon) experimented with elderberries in this region's most famous export.

Champagne fairs drew less attendance as Genoese merchants developed trade routes to the kontors of this organization in Bruges. This trade organization's cogs sailed from its center at Lübeck across the North and Baltic seas.

Perhaps the most famous of the Champagne fairs were the "hot" and "cold" fairs of this city. This city names an agreement that was confirmed by the Treaty of Amiens and paved the way for the Dauphin (DOO-fan) Charles to become king of France.

answers: Mumbai, Maharashtra, India [or Bombay] (the film is Slumdog Millionaire)
parts: Name this city that experienced a series of 1993 bombings which are chronicled in Anurag Kashyap's film Black Friday. Vikas Swarup's novel Q & A was a loose inspiration for another film set in this city's Dharavi (dah-rah-vee) slum.

Mumbai's suburb of Goregaon (goh-ray-ga-oh) is home to an integrated studio complex named after this industry's "father," Dadasaheb Phalke. This Hindu-language film industry makes up the largest percentage of all Indian film output.

The film studio Wakaliwood based out of this city's slum of Wakaliga (wah-kah-LEE-guh) has produced low-budget action films such as Who Killed Captain Alex?. This city's slum of Kamwokya (KAM-woe-kyah) is the birthplace of Bobi Wine.

answers: a fishing rod [accept "Buying a Fishing Rod for My Grandfather"]
temple [accept Guandi Temple or Temple of the Golden Pavilion; accept Kinkaku-ji]
parts: Name this fiberglass object, which the narrator of that short story buys after seeing it in a store window and then stores on top of his toilet tank.

The narrator recalls his grandfather's death at the end of this author's story "Buying a Fishing Rod for My Grandfather." In a novel by this author, a character known as "I" is misdiagnosed with cancer.

In his journey to his grandfather's home, the narrator remembers one of these places named Guandi was struck by lightning. Mizoguchi (miz-oh-goo-chee) burns down a title one of these places in a Yukio Mishima novel.

answers: fonts [or outline fonts or font files or typefaces; accept font hinting; prompt on text, words, strings, characters, symbols or other similar answers]
parts: Name these mathematical objects, which name a type of easily scalable graphics contrasted with raster graphics. In general, these objects are defined by a direction and a magnitude.
Vector graphics often use these curves based on Bernstein polynomials to define non-straight paths. They were developed by their French namesake to design the bodies of Renault cars.

Vector graphics were incorporated into Adobe and Apple's standards for these designs, called "Type 1" and "TrueType" respectively. The process of "hinting" aligns these designs with rasterized pixel grids.

answers: Critique of Judgment [or Kritik der Urteilskraft]
Susanne Langer [or Susanne Katherina Knauth Langer]
parts: Name this 1790 book which outlines a four-step reflective process of finding something agreeable, beautiful, sublime, or good.

The Emancipated Spectator by Jacques Ranciere and Contemplating Art by Jerrold Levinson are, along with the Critique of Judgment, part of what philosophical field that considers the meaning and value of art?

This philosopher's last book, Mind: An Essay on Human Feeling, is a full theory of the psychology of aesthetics. This author of 1942's Philosophy in a New Key was the first American woman to achieve worldwide renown as an academic philosopher.

answers: Jack Daniel [or Jack Daniel's Whiskey; do not accept "Jack Daniels" alone]
IRS [or Internal Revenue Service; or Bureau of Internal Revenue]
parts: Name this brewer who was taught distilling techniques from the former slave Nathan Green and raised by the preacher Dan Call.

A regional superintendent of this organization named John MacDonald helped brewers to avoid spirits taxes in the Whiskey Ring Scandal. The Revenue Act of 1862 first created this organization to collect an income tax, which it still does today.

Jack Daniel's business suffered after the passage of this act that was meant to enforce the 18th Amendment. This act was passed by a namesake Minnesota senator and became invalid after the passage of the 21st Amendment.
Name this religion, whose members founded The Epoch Times newspaper in the United States. The 610 Office was set up by one government solely to persecute followers of this religion.

The 610 Office was set up by this Chinese premier as part of his campaign against Falun Gong. Under this premier, China officially received Hong Kong and Macau from the United Kingdom and Portugal, respectively.

The Epoch Times claims that Jiang orchestrated a self-immolation hoax in this location to draw negative press towards the Falun Gong. This Beijing location was the site of pro-democracy protests on June 4th, 1989.
